Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Extensible Personalization of Spatial and Spatio-temporal Database Management Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to allow database users to enjoy high quality personalized answers for their spatial and spatio-temporal queries, without sacrificing the query execution efficiency. As the concept of personalization is subjective, there are plethora of approaches that define the meaning and contents of a high quality personalized answer. This project does not aim to provide more definitions of personalization, instead, it provides a system-oriented approach that can accommodate most of the existing and future definitions in one highly efficient database engine.

To achieve its goal, this project employs an extensible approach where core database modules for personalized queries are realized only once inside the database engine, and used many times in different ways to support a wide variety of personalized queries. The project provides such extensible core modules for:
(a) single-table operations, e.g., selection and aggregations,
(b) multi-table operations, e.g., join,
(c) operations with adaptive cost that can only be computed online, and
(d) handling uncertain data.
With these extensible modules, registering a new personalization definition becomes as easy as plugging few modules in an easy-to-use interface. Once plugged in, the new personalized definition lives in the database engine, and enjoys the power of the extensible modules for query processor, optimizer, and indexing.

Such extensible approach is highly attractive to industry as it gives minimal changes in the database engine to support wide variety of personalized queries, as well as orders of magnitude performance over existing approaches that are built on top of database systems. Besides its impact on industry, this project will have significant broader impact across multiple segments of society that include enhancing productivity, graduate and undergraduate student education, outreach to K-12 students, curriculum development, and tutorial presentations. Publications, technical reports, open-source software, and experimental data from this research are disseminated via the project web site (http://www.cs.umn.edu/~mokbel/career).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project started by changing the way that database systems deal with queries by taking into account the surrounding context and user preferences. This results in changing the classical query of "find my nearest restaurant for lunch" to be "find my best restaurant for lunch", where the meaning of "best" could be different based on the surrounding context and the current user preferences. The project then went ahead for integrating database systems with recommender systems into an open-source DB engine, termed RecDB. RecDB, downloaded more than 10,000 times, realize the recommender system functionality as built-in inside the core of database engines. This makes recommender systems much more efficient, scalable, and able to cope up with the stream of online changes that would affect the recommendation functionality. All source code, examples, and manuals of RecDB are available at: http://www.cs.umn.edu/~sarwat/RecDB/


The project has also developed Sindbad as a location-based social network. Sindbad distinguishes itself from other social networks where every aspect of social interaction becomes location-aware. For example, posted messages in Sindbad have inherent spatial extents composed of the location of the posted message and the spatial range where this message is in effect. Sindbad supports three new services beyond traditional social networking services, namely, location-aware news feed, location-aware ranking and location-aware recommendation. The location-aware news feed customizes the news feed for each user per the current user location. The location-aware ranking service ranks such news feed based on how close each news feed item to the current user location. The location-aware recommendation service injects location-awareness into the core of the recommendation functionality that is used to recommend restaurants, ads, or any items to the social network users.

As a matter of infrastructure building, the project has developed the Minnesota Traffic Generator (MNTG), available at http://mntg.cs.umn.edu/. MNTG is a web-based traffic generater, where users can select any area anywhere in the world, and request to generate road network traffic in the selected area using three different traffic generation models. Once the traffic generation is done, an email will be sent to the requesting user with a link to download the requested traffic. To date, MNTG was used more than 5,000 times.


Finally, the project went ahead for scalability, where it develops the SpatialHadoop system as the first full-fledged open-source Map-Reduce-based system that is geared toward indexing, querying, and visualizing Big Spatial Data. SpatialHadoop was downloaded more than 80,000 times within one year of its release, and become the de facto system when dealing with Big Spatial Data. All source code, tutorials, and examples of SpatialHadoop, along with about a terra byte of freely available Big Spatial Data can be downloaded from: http://spatialhadoop.cs.umn.edu/

The project has supported nine PhD students, six of them have already graduated, securing jobs in major academia and research labs. Publications and results coming our from this projects are available in: http://www.cs.umn.edu/~mokbel/career/
